text: There are several figures named Pelagon (Ancient Greek: Πελάγων, -όνος) in Greek mythology. * Pelagon, king of Phocis and son of Amphidamas. He gave Cadmus the cow that was to guide him to Boeotia.Pausanias, Graeciae Descriptio 9.12.1Scholia on Euripides, Phoenician Women 638Pseudo-Apollodorus, Bibliotheca 3.4.1 * Pelagon or Pelasgus, son of the river-god Asopus by Metope.Pseudo-Apollodorus, Bibliotheca 3.12.6Diodorus Siculus, Bibliotheca historica 4.72.1 * Pelagon, one of the suitors of Hippodamia before Pelops.Pausanias, Graeciae Descriptio 6.21.11 * Pelagon, one of the Calydonian hunters.Ovid, Metamorphoses 8.360 * Pelagon or Pelegon, who is given in the Iliad as the father of the Paeonian warrior Asteropaeus, son of the river-god Axius and Periboea, the daughter of Acessamenus.Homer, Iliad 21.142 Presumably this Pelagon was the eponymous founder of Pelagonia. * Pelagon, a native of Pylos who fought under Nestor in the Trojan War.Homer, Iliad 4.295 * Pelagon, an "illustrious" companion of the hero Sarpedon during the Trojan War, who removes Tlepolemus' spear from Sarpedon's thigh.Homer, Iliad 5.695; scholia on this line inform that he was also referred to as "Selagon" ==Notes== == References == * Diodorus Siculus, The Library of History translated by Charles Henry Oldfather.
